Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – Project Management
Code: B126
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,776.00
International Tuition: $17,925.00
Location: St. James Campus
Program Overview: Learn how to manage projects effectively and graduate with a wide range of project management skills.
Skills gained: Evaluating project management impact on HR, management, financial, and business strategies and practices, creating and executing project plans, managing trade-offs and responding promptly to issues and opportunities, using accounting and financial skills for effective project management.
Programs related: Project Management (Postgraduate) (B415), Business Administration – Project Management (with work experience) (B156), International Business Management (Postgraduate) (B411)

Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers various business programs, including those in Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, Marketing, and Financial Services, some of which have earned international accreditation from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). These accredited programs include advanced diplomas and diplomas in Accounting and Finance, as well as the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program. George Brown College is one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned ACBSP accreditation.

The Project Management program at the Centre for Business provides students with opportunities to learn accounting and financial skills to manage projects effectively, as well as collaborating professionally and respectfully with teams and stakeholders. Students can attend an information session about the project management programs through a recording below.

Field education is available to students, offering real-life experience that employers demand. In addition to on-the-job work experience, George Brown College endeavors to provide field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients. More information about field education can be found on the Centre for Business website.

Graduates of this program will have demonstrated knowledge, skills, and abilities related to both business in general and project management in particular. Potential positions may include assistant project manager, junior project manager/coordinator, project manager, project coordinator, or business project manager. George Brown College is recognized as a Global Registered Education Provider with the Project Management Institute (PMI), and graduates of any of the college's courses listed on PMI's Registered Education Provider portal can apply for either the Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) or the Project Management Professional (PMP) certification.

To graduate from the B126 program, students need to complete 36 courses: 31 mandatory courses.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Project Management Program B126 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
To graduate from the B126 program, students must complete a total of 36 courses. This includes 31 mandatory courses, 2 business electives, and 3 general education electives. Students may be required to take certain prerequisite courses before progressing to other courses, such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation). These courses do not count towards the 36 required courses and will incur additional charges.

Students are required to complete three general education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students must make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation and can do so during the day or through Continuing Education. Students should check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to those in the full-time program, as some courses may not be offered every semester.

The following is a list of courses for the first two semesters:

Semester 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (none)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (none)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (none)
- HRM 1008: Fundamentals of HR Management (none)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (none)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I (none)

Semester 2:
- BUS 1040: Project Management (none)
- ECON 1031: Microeconomics (none)
- COMM 1034: Professional Communications I (COMM 2000)
- COMP 1115: Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1010)
- MATH 1095: Math for Business & Management II (MATH 1008)
- PSY 1129: Organizational Behaviour (none)

Context:
Program Offered:
- Retail Management (MGMT 2037)
- Customer Service (MGMT 2036)
- Coaching for Effective Performance Management (HRM 2027)
- Applied Business Planning (BUS 3015)
- Field Based Advanced Coaching (HRM 2030)
- Quality Improvement through Lean/Six Sigma (NONE)
- Human Resource Management (HRM 2027, HRM 2030)

Course Prerequisites:
- MARK 1020 for Retail Management, Customer Service, Applied Business Planning, and HRM 2030
- ACCT 2031 and MATH 1008 for Applied Business Planning
- HRM 1008 for Coaching for Effective Performance Management
- Interview only for MGMT 3015

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate will be able to:
1. Evaluate the impact of global issues on an organization’s business opportunities using an environmental scan.
2. Apply principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility and ethics to support an organization's business initiatives.
3. Assess and use current concepts/systems and technologies to support an organization's business initiatives.
4. Conduct and present research to support business decision-making.
5. Plan, implement and evaluate projects by applying project management principles.
6. Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations and business practices.
7. Apply human resource practices to support management objectives and the organization’s goals.
8. Use accounting and financial principles to support the management and operations of an organization.
9. Assess marketing and sales concepts and strategies and apply them to the needs of an organization.
10. Outline principles of supply chain management and operations management and assess their impact on the operations of an organization.
11. Participate in the development of a business plan.
12. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance in the business field.
13. Outline strategies used to manage risks in an organization's business activities.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2023): $3,776.00 *
- International Tuition (Fall 2024): $17,925.00 **
- Additional Costs: Not provided in the text

* Amounts listed are the estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
** Amounts listed are the estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024. Tuition fees are subject to board approval.

Context: Programs starting in Fall 2024. Tuition fees are subject to board approval. International Students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information. This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria. Applicants require an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions. Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in the program. International Students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Information sessions are held on a regular basis.
